concern: As the title says my roommate doesn’t clean up after themself. Now our room isn’t a complete disaster and it’s mainly their side (plus our bathroom but it’s kinda 70/30 on who makes the most mess of it) but they just don’t really clean up. They have cups and cans and bottles all over their nightstand and desk and have even had a cup under their bed on the dresser before, and they’re never empty either. They also go home every weekend so they don’t really have dishes or real food here so they’re all Starbucks and Dunkin’ cups, so half full coffees just sitting there separating for weeks as they go home and come back. They do sorta clean it after a few weeks, I’ve seen them bag up the cups and other garbage, but they don’t take it out. They have bags full of garbage in the corner on their side of the room and our rooms not big so it’s starting to creep towards our closet almost in the way of it. As for the bathroom they leave hair everywhere and I know it’s theirs and not mine because it’s their little rubber bands with the hair. Now like I said I am also at fault for the the bathroom being messy but I try to keep it somewhat clean by taking out the garbage and have cleaned the shower drain but they don’t even try to clean up a bit. I don’t know how they don’t get embarrassed when they have a friend over or even just with me being here. I get embarrassed having 2 cans on my desk and a few dirty forks or spoons for a few days because I’m too tired to wash them yet. Otherwise they’re a good roommate it’s just they never clean. I should also say they had a single room last year so it definitely feels like part of the reason since they would be used to not sharing a space but I want to have friends over and I’m embarrassed for my roommate. I don’t really know how to tell them to take their garbage out without sounding like a bitch and I already accepted I’m gonna be cleaning our bathroom alone.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and support you. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share anything that's on your mind.
client: Thanks. I've been thinking about how to approach a situation with my roommate. It's been stressing me out a bit.
therapist: It sounds like this situation is really weighing on you. Can you share more about what's been happening with your roommate?
client: Sure, it's just that their cleaning habits are bothering me. It's not like they're a bad person, but our shared space is suffering a bit.

therapist: It seems like you're feeling overwhelmed because of the impact your roommate's cleaning habits have on your shared space. How do you feel this is affecting you, and what might you want to address with them?
client: client: It's making me feel uneasy in my own room and kind of embarrassed to have people over. I want to address it with them without causing any tension or coming off as rude.

It sounds like maintaining a comfortable and welcoming space is important to you. What do you think might help you share your feelings with your roommate in a way that aligns with your desire for a peaceful conversation?
client: I guess I could try to have a calm chat with them, maybe find a way to bring it up when we're both relaxed. It's just tricky because I don't want to make things awkward between us.
Therapist: It's understandable to want to keep things comfortable between you and your roommate. What do you think might help you feel more confident about having this conversation?

Client: Maybe if I plan out what I want to say beforehand, it'll help me feel more prepared. I could also approach it by focusing on how we can both benefit from a cleaner space rather than just pointing out their mess.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach. Based on what you've said, some options could include planning your conversation points in advance or even writing them down, and focusing on mutual benefits during the discussion. How do these options sound to you, and is there anything else that might help you prepare?
Yeah, planning it out in advance and focusing on the positives sounds like a good plan. Maybe I could even offer to help with cleaning up the first time as a way to get us started.

That's a great plan of action. You've identified a thoughtful approach by preparing what you want to say and focusing on mutual benefits, which can help keep the conversation positive. Offering to help with the cleaning initially shows collaboration and might open a pathway for future cooperation. Remember, you’re aiming for a shared benefit, which is a cleaner, more comfortable space for both of you.

As you move forward, you might consider setting a small goal for yourself, like having this conversation within the next week. And remember, you’re not alone in this. You’ve shown a lot of insight and willingness to address the issue constructively, and that’s a strong step toward resolution.

Feel free to touch base if you need more support or want to discuss how it went. You're doing great, and I’m confident you’ll handle this thoughtfully.
Thanks, I appreciate the feedback and support. I'll give it a shot and see how it goes.
